unnormalised: First off, imagine you're riding your Bajaj scooter (the good old days!) and you're trying to impress that neighbour's daughter, Priya. You start slow, then you accelerate real quick because, you know, *image*. Differential Calculus is basically figuring out *how quickly* your speed is changing at any given moment. That's the "differential" part. Think of it as the scooter's speedometer on steroids, constantly telling you not just your speed, but how FAST your speed is *becoming* faster (or slower, if you see a cow wandering onto the road).

unnormalised: Now, for the "calculus" part. That's where you actually *calculate* this rate of change. We're talking slopes of curves, y-axis changes divided by x-axis changes, and a bunch of other stuff that probably made your head hurt back in Class 11 & 12. But don't worry, you don't need to remember the formulas right now. Just know that it involves taking tiny, *tiny* steps (infinitesimals, they call them – sounds like a fancy brand of mosquito repellent, doesn't it?) and figuring out what's happening between them.

Calculus. Want to figure out the best angle to kick a cricket ball for maximum distance? Calculus. Want to predict how many samosas your neighbourhood uncle will eat at the next Diwali party based on his past performance? Okay, maybe not that last one, but you get the idea.

unnormalised: Think of it like this: Differential Calculus is like trying to catch a runaway auto-rickshaw. The rickshaw represents the function, and you represent the derivative. You're trying to figure out where it's going (increasing or decreasing), how fast it's going (the rate of change), and maybe even anticipate when it's going to suddenly swerve to avoid a pothole. It’s chaotic, messy, and sometimes you just want to give up and have a chai, but hey, that's life!

unnormalised: And if all else fails, just remember that the derivative of a constant is zero. Which basically means, if you're not changing, you're not differentiating (which, ironically, means you're not being very interesting). So get out there, change something, and maybe even learn a little calculus along the way. You never know, it might just help you impress Priya after all (or at least understand why your scooter guzzles petrol faster than you can say "petrol price hike"). My suggestion? Start with Khan Academy... Or maybe that neighbour's daughter can explain it better? Ask her for notes, pretending that you forgot yours. Mention something about "derivatives" sounding cool! Good luck, beta!
